citeinfo.title: Biotic soil crusts of Oregon's shrub steppe: Community composition in relation to soil chemistry, climate, and livestock activity

descript.abstract: Biotic soil crust cover and composition were examined at nine shrub-steppe sites in central and eastern Oregon. Livestock and excluded transects were established at each site. Data were collected on biotic soil crust cover, vascular plant species, soil surface pH and electrical conductivity, and other variables. It was found by gradient analysis that differences in community composition were most strongly related to soil pH, electrical conductivity, and Calcareous Index Value. Other important variables were elevation, precipitation, aspect and temperature. Total crust cover was highest at sites with lower pH, electrical conductivity and Calcareous Index Value. Dominant species differed significantly between the more calcareous sites with higher pH, and the less calcareous, lower pH sites. The livestock presence gradient was not as important in the data as the strong soil chemistry and climate gradients. Overall community composition of soil crust species was different between grazed and long-ungrazed sites. Comparison of grazed and long-ungrazed sites showed lower cover of biotic crusts, nitrogen-fixing lichens, crust-dominated soil surface roughness, and lower species richness. Biotic soil crusts appear to be sensitive indicators of disturbance and there seem to be strong compositional differences in shrub steppe crust communities of Oregon that are correlated with regional soil and climate gradients.

taxonomy.taxongen: Biological soil crusts are composed of a community of organisms that include fungi, bacteria, algae, and other taxa.
